article.title: Detection and manipulation of methylation in blood cancer DNA using terahertz radiation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the intensity of the THz resonance peak in Figure 1a represent?
choices: The type of cancer cell line.
The amount of unmethylated DNA in cancer cells.
The amount of methyl-DNA bonds in cancer DNA.
The wavelength of the THz radiation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the baseline correction shown in Figure 1b?
choices: To normalize the data for all cancer types.
To isolate the resonance peak associated with methylated DNA.
To identify the exact frequency of the methyl-DNA bond.
To compare the results obtained from THz-TDS and ELISA.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the similar resonance frequencies observed in Figure 1c?
choices: The characteristic energy of methylated DNA is similar across different blood cancers.
The degree of global DNA methylation is consistent across different blood cancers.
THz-TDS cannot differentiate between different types of blood cancers.
Baseline correction was not successful in all samples.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the comparison between THz-TDS and ELISA results in Figure 1d suggest?
choices: ELISA is a more accurate method for measuring global DNA methylation.
THz-TDS can only be used to measure DNA methylation in specific cancer types.
THz-TDS has the potential to be a direct and quantitative method for measuring global DNA methylation.
There is no correlation between the results obtained from THz-TDS and ELISA.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2a, what is the expected effect of high-power THz radiation on the methylated DNA?
choices: Ionization of the DNA molecule.
Breaking the bond between DNA and the methyl group.
Amplification of the THz resonance signal.
Changing the sequence of the DNA molecule.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the amplitude decrease in the THz resonance peak shown in Figure 2b?
choices: It indicates the degradation of the entire DNA molecule.
It suggests a reduction in the degree of global methylation.
It demonstrates the ionization of the methyl group.
It shows the change in the refractive index of the sample.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the bandpass filter used in the high-power THz radiation system (Figure 2c)?
choices: To amplify the THz radiation.
To block all THz radiation.
To select a specific frequency range matching the methylated DNA resonance.
To measure the power of the THz beam.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the bandwidth-limited THz radiation expected to have minimal impact on other DNA structures (Figure 2e)?
choices: Other DNA structures are not sensitive to THz radiation.
The energy of the narrowed THz radiation is primarily targeted towards the collective vibrations associated with the methyl-DNA bond.
The bandpass filter completely eliminates all other frequencies except 1.7 THz.
The exposure time is too short to affect other DNA structures.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of artificially methylating the HEK 293T DNA (Figure 3a)?
choices: To induce cancer in the cells.
To make the DNA detectable by THz radiation.
To create a controlled sample with a known degree of methylation.
To enhance the binding energy of the methyl-DNA bond.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the reduced amplitude of the resonance peak in the M-293T_expd sample (Figure 3c)?
choices: The high-power THz radiation has destroyed the DNA molecule.
The resonance frequency of the methylated DNA has shifted.
The degree of methylation in the M-293T sample has been reduced.
The baseline correction algorithm was not successful.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the similar methylation degree measured by both THz-TDS and ELISA in Figure 3c?
choices: It validates the use of THz-TDS as a method for quantifying DNA methylation.
It suggests that ELISA is a more accurate method than THz-TDS.
It shows that the demethylation process is incomplete.
It demonstrates the saturation of the resonance peak.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3d tell us about the relationship between demethylation efficiency and exposure time?
choices: Longer exposure times are always more effective for demethylation.
Demethylation efficiency appears to saturate after a certain exposure time.
Exposure time has no effect on the efficiency of demethylation.
The optimal exposure time varies depending on the cell type.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary purpose of the experiment depicted in Figure 4?
choices: To identify the resonance frequency of methylated DNA in different blood cancers.
To investigate the demethylation effects of resonant high-power THz radiation on blood cancer DNA.
To compare the accuracy of THz-TDS and ELISA in measuring DNA methylation.
To study the impact of demethylation on cancer cell viability.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different reduction ratios observed in various blood cancer cell lines suggest (Figure 4b)?
choices: The effectiveness of THz demethylation can vary depending on the cell type.
All blood cancers respond to THz radiation in a similar manner.
The ELISA method is not reliable for quantifying demethylation.
The control samples were contaminated.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a possible explanation for the variation in demethylation efficiency across cell lines according to the authors?
choices: Differences in DNA sequence.
Differences in cell size and morphology.
Differences in collective vibrations associated with the arrangement or distribution of DNA methylation.
Differences in sensitivity to THz radiation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is a potential benefit of using THz radiation for DNA demethylation in a clinical setting?
choices: It requires the use of toxic chemicals.
It is an invasive procedure.
It offers a non-invasive and potentially targeted approach to manipulate DNA methylation.
It is only effective for a limited number of cancer types.
